problems.title: Round Trip
problems.statementHtml:
Petya and Vasya love participating in Codeforces contests. Vasya made a bet with Petya that he will take part in more rated rounds than him. Initially, Vasya's rating is R0R0. There will be nn rounds conducted in total, each of one of two types:

In an unrated round, Vasya cannot change his rating. If Vasya's rating before a rated round was RR, then for any non-negative integer xx between R−DR−D and R+DR+D (inclusive) Vasya can adopt a strategy such that his rating becomes exactly xx afterwards (here DD is a positive integer). Note that rating may never become negative.

Help Vasya determine the maximum number of rated rounds he can participate in.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤10001≤t≤1000). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains four integers: R0,X,D,nR0,X,D,n (0≤R0≤1090≤R0≤109, 1≤X≤1091≤X≤109, 1≤D,n≤10001≤D,n≤1000) — Vasya's initial rating, the rating threshold between divisions, the maximum rating delta, and the number of rounds.

The second line of each test case contains a string of size nn. The string will only contain the characters "1" and "2", representing div. 1 and div. 2 rounds respectively.

The sum of nn across all test cases does not exceed 3⋅1043⋅104.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, print a single integer — the maximum number of rated rounds Vasya can participate in.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first example, since R0≥XR0≥X, each div. 2 round is unrated for Vasya, so his rating never changes. Therefore, he cannot make any round rated for himself, and the answer is 00.

In the second example, one of the optimal sequences of ratings after each round is: 2098→2103→2101→2099→2097→2097→20922098→2103→2101→2099→2097→2097→2092.

problems.title: Make Connected
problems.statementHtml:
You are given an n×nn×n grid where some cells are colored black, and the rest are white. You may paint some of the white cells black to achieve the following conditions:

You can't paint black cells white.

Determine whether it is possible to paint some white cells black in order to satisfy all the conditions.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤10001≤t≤1000). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line contains an integer nn (1≤n≤1001≤n≤100) — the size of the grid.

The following nn lines contain nn characters each — the grid description, where each character represents a cell:

  • . — a white cell;
  • # — a black cell.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 20002000.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, print "YES" if it is possible to paint some white cells black to satisfy all the conditions, and "NO" otherwise.

You may print each letter in any case (uppercase or lowercase). For example, the strings "yEs", "yes", "Yes", and "YES" will all be recognized as a positive answer.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, there are no black cells, so we must paint one cell black.

In the second and third test cases, the grid satisfies all the conditions from the very beginning.

In the fourth test case, one of the possible solutions is:

##.
.##
..#

In the fifth test case, the grid violates the "No three consecutive black cells should be aligned vertically or horizontally" condition from the very beginning, so there is no solution.

In the sixth test case, it can be shown that it is impossible to achieve a connected grid without violating the condition about three consecutive black cells.

problems.title: Loyalty
problems.statementHtml:
You are a customer in a store and want to buy nn items. Each item ii has a price aiai such that 1≤ai≤X1≤ai≤X, where XX is a loyalty factor.

Your loyalty level in the store is defined as ⌊SX⌋⌊SX⌋, where SS is the total cost of items purchased so far. Initially, S=0S=0.

If you buy an item with price pp and your loyalty level increases as a result of this purchase, you earn pp bonus points.

Your task is to find the maximum number of bonus points you can earn by choosing an optimal order of purchase for the items.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤2⋅1041≤t≤2⋅104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn (1≤n≤1051≤n≤105) and XX (1≤X≤1091≤X≤109) — the number of items and the loyalty factor.

The second line of each test case contains nn integers a1a1, a2a2, ……, anan (1≤ai≤X1≤ai≤X) — the prices of the items.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 105105.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, output two lines.

The first line should contain a single integer — the maximum number of bonus points that can be earned.

The second line should contain nn integers — the prices of the items in an order of purchase that maximizes the number of bonus points.

If there are several orders that maximize the number of bonus points, you can output any of them.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case:

  1. After buying the first item S=1S=1, loyalty level is 0;
  2. After buying the second item S=3S=3, this increases loyalty level to 11 and earns 22 bonus points;
  3. After buying the third item S=5S=5, this increases loyalty level to 22 and earns 22 bonus points;
  4. After buying the fourth item S=7S=7, this increases loyalty level to 33 and earns 22 bonus points;
  5. After buying the fifth item S=9S=9, this increases loyalty level to 44 and earns 22 bonus points;
  6. After buying the sixth item S=11S=11, this increases loyalty level to 55 and earns 22 bonus points;
  7. After buying the seventh item S=12S=12, this increases loyalty level to 66 and earns 11 bonus point;
  8. After buying the eighth item S=13S=13;
  9. After buying the ninth item S=14S=14, this increases loyalty level to 77 and earns 11 bonus point;
  10. After buying the tenth item S=15S=15.

Overall we got 1212 bonus points.

In the second test case:

  1. After buying the first four items S=8S=8, loyalty level is 0;
  2. After buying the last item S=13S=13, this increases loyalty level to 11 and earns 55 bonus points.

In the third test case:

  1. After buying the first eight items S=20S=20, loyalty level is 0;
  2. After buying the ninth item S=30S=30, this increases loyalty level to 11 and earns 1010 bonus points;
  3. After buying the tenth item S=51S=51, this increases loyalty level to 22 and earns 2121 bonus points;
  4. After buying the eleventh item S=73S=73, this increases loyalty level to 33 and earns 2222 bonus points.

problems.title: Locked Out
problems.statementHtml:
An array bb is good if there do not exist indices 1≤i<j≤|b|1≤i<j≤|b| such that bj−bi=1bj−bi=1.

You are given an integer. array a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an. Determine the minimum number of elements that need to be removed from the given array so that it becomes a good array.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤6⋅1041≤t≤6⋅104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains an integer nn (1≤n≤3⋅1051≤n≤3⋅105) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line of each test case contains nn integers a1a1, a2a2, ……, anan (1≤ai≤n1≤ai≤n) — the elements of the array.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 3⋅1053⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, print a single integer — the minimum number of elements that need to be removed from the array to make it a good array.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, the array is good from the very beginning, so nothing needs to be removed from it.

In the second test case, the optimal solution is to remove the second and fourth elements of the array, which will result in 11, 33, 55 array.

In the third test case, the array is good from the very beginning.

In the fourth test case, the array is good from the very beginning.

In the fifth test case, the optimal solution is to remove the fourth element of the array, which will result in 11, 77, 11, 55, 77, 11 array.

In the sixth test case, one of the optimal solutions is to remove the first and fourth elements of the array, which will result in 22, 55, 55, 55 array.

problems.title: Left is Always Right
problems.statementHtml:
Consider a binary string of length nn and an odd number kk. We will call the binary string good if for each substring of length kk, the leftmost character of the substring occurs more than the other.

For example, if k=3k=3, 000101 is a good string, because for all substrings of length 3 (000, 001, 010, and 101) the first character of the substring occurs more than the other character. On the other hand, 1011 is not good, because the property is false for 011.

Given a pattern of length nn consisting of characters 0, 1 and ?, find the number of ways to replace question marks with 0 or 1, such that the resulting binary string is good. Since the answer may be large, find it modulo 998244353998244353.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1031≤t≤103). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and kk (3≤k≤n≤1053≤k≤n≤105, kk is odd). The second line contains nn characters 0, 1 or ? — the pattern.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 105105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, print the number of ways to replace ? with 0 or 1 such that the resulting string is good, modulo 998244353998244353.
problems.noteHtml: In the first example, three valid ways to make the pattern good are 00000, 00001, and 00101. In the second example, the only invalid way (out of 16 total ways) is 1001001.

problems.title: SubMST
problems.statementHtml:
You are given an undirected unweighted tree TT with nn vertices.

Define a complete undirected weighted graph GG with nn vertices, where the weight of the edge between vertices uu and vv in GG is equal to the distance between the two vertices in the original tree.

For every possible subset of vertices, consider the minimum spanning tree (MST) of the subgraph of GG induced by that subset of vertices. Compute the sum of the weights of the MST for all possible subsets of vertices.

As this number is big, you are only required to output the sum modulo 109+7109+7.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤100001≤t≤10000). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line contains an integer nn (1≤n≤50001≤n≤5000), the number of vertices in the tree.

The following n−1n−1 lines contains two integers uu and vv (1≤u,v≤n1≤u,v≤n), representing an edge between vertices uu and vv in the tree.

It is guaranteed that the sum of n2n2 over all test cases does not exceed 5000250002.
problems.outputSpecHtml: Output a single integer, the sum of the MST weights for all possible subsets of vertices, modulo 109+7109+7.
problems.noteHtml: The first test case is illustrated below. The subsets with at most one vertex are ommited since they have a weight of 00 and therefore do not contribute to the sum.

problems.title: Bitwise And Equals
problems.statementHtml:
There is an array of integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an, and there is an integer XX.

You may perform the following operation zero or more times:

Let a′a′ be the final state of the array. Your goal is to perform the operation above the smallest number of times such that a′1&a′2&…&a′n=Xa1′&a2′&…&an′=X. && denotes the bitwise AND operation.

There are qq such query integers XX: X1,X2,…,XqX1,X2,…,Xq. Compute the answer for each X=XiX=Xi. Note that all queries are processed separately and independently, from the same initial state aa.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains integers nn and qq (2≤n≤2000002≤n≤200000, 1≤q≤2000001≤q≤200000) — the length of the array and the number of queries.

The second line contains integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (for each ii, 0≤ai<2200≤ai<220).

The next qq lines each contain a single integer XiXi (0≤Xi<2200≤Xi<220).
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each query ii out of qq, print the smallest number of operations to get to the array a′a′ such that a′1&a′2&…&a′n=Xia1′&a2′&…&an′=Xi.

It's possible to show, that it's always possible to obtain such array a′a′ in finite number of operations.
problems.noteHtml:
For the first query, you can increase i=3i=3 (ai=7ai=7) and get the array a=[6,4,8,5,4]a=[6,4,8,5,4], then 6&4&8&5&4=06&4&8&5&4=0.

For the third query, original array already matches condition: 6&4&7&5&4=46&4&7&5&4=4.

problems.title: Cycle Sort
problems.statementHtml:
You are given two integer arrays a0,…,an−1 and b0,…,bm−1. Each integer among 1,…,n+m is present exactly once among a0,…,an−1,b0,…,bm−1.

We perform k operations on the arrays. Namely, for each integer i from 0 to k−1 in this order

Determine the final state of both arrays after all k operations are completed.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases t (1≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains three integers n,m,k (1≤n,m≤2⋅105, 0≤k≤1018).

The second line contains n integers a0,…,an−1.

The third line contains m integers b0,…,bm−1.

It is guaranteed that the joint sequence a0,…,an−1,b0,…,bm−1 is a permutation of integers from 1 to n+m.

The sum of n+m over all testcases doesn't exceed 2⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each testcase, print two lines — the states of the arrays a0,…,an−1 and b0,…,bm−1 after the k operations are performed as described above.
problems.noteHtml:
The action sequence for the first example

iimodnimodmcomparisonactionarray aarray b
0003>1swap a0 and b0[1, 4][3, 5, 2]
1114<5nothing[1, 4][3, 5, 2]
2021<2nothing[1, 4][3, 5, 2]
3104>3swap a1 and b0[1, 3][4, 5, 2]
4011<5nothing[1, 3][4, 5, 2]

tutorial.contentHtml:
We hope you've enjoyed the problems! (Certain problem editorials below may appear a bit late due to Polygon lag)

2161A - Round Trip

Since div.1 rounds are always rated for all participants, we need to maximize the number of div.2 rounds. This means we should always try to decrease our rating until it reaches X−1 so we can participate in div.2 rounds too. After that, every round will be rated.
